abstract: Expanded simple tandem repeat (ESTR) loci belong to the class of highly unstable loci in the mouse genome. The mechanisms underlying the very high spontaneous instability at these loci still remain poorly understood. Using single-molecule polymerase chain reaction, here we have compared the pattern of mutation accumulation in tissues with different proliferation capacities in male mice of age 12, 26, 48, and 96 weeks. In the nonproliferating brain, we did not observe any measurable age-related accumulation of ESTR mutations. In contrast, a highly elevated frequency of ESTR mutation was detected in the sperm samples taken from old mice; similar changes were also observed in the bone marrow tissue. The spectra of ESTR mutations accumulated in all tissues of young and old mice did not significantly differ. Taken together, these data clearly imply that spontaneous ESTR mutations occur almost exclusively in replication-proficient cells. To gain further insights into the mechanisms of ESTR mutation, we developed a stochastic model of age-related mutation accumulation. The observed spectra of ESTR mutants accumulated in the brain and sperm were fairly accurately approximated assuming the values of ESTR mutation rate, ranging from 0.01 to 0.04 per cell division. As these estimates dramatically exceed those for protein-coding genes and microsatellite loci, our data therefore suggest that ESTRs represent one of the most unstable loci in the mammalian genome. The results of our study also imply that ESTR loci can be regarded as a class of expanded microsatellites, with the mechanism of spontaneous mutation most probably attributed to replication slippage

1
Age-related accumulation of mutations reveals mechanisms of spontaneous mutation at 
tandem repeat DNA loci in mice 
Research Article 
Robert J. Hardwick,* Michael V. Tretyakov,† and Yuri E. Dubrova* 
 
*Department of Genetics; and †Department of Mathematics, University of Leicester, 
Leicester, United Kingdom 
 
Correspondence: 
Yuri E. Dubrova 
Department of Genetics, University of Leicester, University Road, Leicester LE1 7RH, 
United Kingdom 
Tel:  +44 (116) 252 5654 
Fax:  +44 (116) 252 3378 
E-mail: yed2@le.ac.uk 
 
Key words: Expanded simple tandem repeat loci, mutation, age, mouse 
Running head: Mouse age and tandem repeat mutations 
 2
Abstract 
 
Expanded simple tandem repeat (ESTR) loci belong to the class of highly unstable loci in the 
mouse genome. The mechanisms underlying the very high spontaneous instability at these 
loci still remain poorly understood. Using single-molecule PCR, here we have compared the 
pattern of mutation accumulation in tissues with different proliferation capacities in male 
mice of age 12, 26, 48 and 96 weeks. In the non-proliferating brain we did not observe any 
measurable age-related accumulation of ESTR mutations. In contrast, a highly elevated 
frequency of ESTR mutation was detected in the sperm samples taken from old mice; similar 
changes were also observed in the bone marrow tissue. The spectra of ESTR mutations 
accumulated in all tissues of young and old mice did not significantly differ. Taken together, 
these data clearly imply that spontaneous ESTR mutations occur almost exclusively in 
replication-proficient cells. To gain further insights into the mechanisms of ESTR mutation, 
we developed a stochastic model of age-related mutation accumulation. The observed spectra 
of ESTR mutants accumulated in the brain and sperm were fairly accurately approximated 
assuming the values of ESTR mutation rate, ranging from 0.01 to 0.04 per cell division. As 
these estimates dramatically exceed those for protein-coding genes and microsatellite loci, 
our data therefore suggest that ESTRs represent the most unstable loci in the mammalian 
genome. The results of our study also imply that ESTR loci can be regarded as a class of 
expanded microsatellites, with the mechanism of spontaneous mutation most probably 
attributed to replication slippage. 
  
 3
Introduction 
 
  Expanded simple tandem repeat (ESTR) DNA loci belong to the class of the most 
unstable loci in the mouse genome. They consist of long homogenous arrays of relatively 
short repeats (4-9 bp) and show a very high spontaneous mutation rate of length changes both 
in germline and somatic cells (Bois et al. 1998). They were originally classified as 
hypervariable mouse minisatellites (Kelly et al. 1989; Gibbs at al. 1993), but have since been 
distinguished from mini- and micro-satellite loci as they possess some unique characteristics 
(Bois et al. 1998). For example, the bulk of spontaneous mutations at GC-rich human 
minisatellites occur in the germline, with only very rare events taking place in somatic cells 
(Jeffreys at al. 1994). In contrast, ESTRs are equally unstable in the germline and somatic 
tissues (Kelly et al. 1989; Gibbs at al. 1993; Barber et al. 2006; 2009; Hatch et al. 2007). 
However, with repeat units of 4-9 base pairs and overall array lengths of up to 22 kb, ESTRs 
are too large for a conventional microsatellite (Ellegren 2004). 
The mechanisms underlying the very high ESTR spontaneous mutation rate still 
remain poorly understood. The first insights into the mechanisms of ESTR mutation were 
obtained from studies on mutation induction at these loci in the germline of male mice 
exposed either to ionizing radiation (Fan et al. 1995; Dubrova et al. 1998; 2000) or chemical 
mutagens (Vilarino-Guell et al. 2003). The data generated by these studies clearly showed 
that the observed increases in ESTR mutation rates cannot be attributed to direct targeting of 
these relatively small genomic loci by mutagens. They also suggested that ESTR mutation 
induction results from DNA damage occurring elsewhere in the genome and subsequent 
indirect mutation at the ESTR loci. Considering these results and the data on ESTR mutation 
rates in the germline of DNA-repair-deficient mice, we proposed that both spontaneous and 
radiation-induced ESTR mutation is a replication-driven process, and most probably 
attributed to replication slippage (Barber et al. 2004). According to our model, the very high 
spontaneous mutation rate at ESTR loci could be directly related to their very large size (up 
to 3500 repeats) and, probably, the presence of hairpin structures within the arrays which 
together may promote polymerase slippages. A comparison of spontaneous ESTR mutation 
frequencies in flow-sorted fractions of the mouse male germ cells provided further support 
for this model (Shanks et al. 2008). Our recent data on the effects of fetal irradiation on 
ESTR mutation frequencies in the germline and somatic tissues of adult mice imply that 
ESTR mutation induction occurs mostly, if not exclusively, in replication-proficient cells 
(Barber et al. 2009). 
The results of these studies therefore suggest that ESTR loci may be regarded as a 
class of expanded microsatellites, where the mechanisms underlying spontaneous mutation 
are replication-driven. It should however be noted that numerous studies have identified a 
unique class of the expanded disease-causing human microsatellites (Mirkin 2007), which 
share a number of common features with mouse ESTR loci. First of all, the size of expanded 
alleles (100+ repeats) is approaching that for the most unstable ESTR loci in the mouse 
genome, whereas for the majority of ‘conventional’ microsatellites it seldom exceeds 50 
repeats (Ellegren 2004). Most importantly, following the expansion, the disease-causing 
human microsatellites become extremely unstable and, in some cases, the frequency of 
accumulated mutations at these loci even exceeds that for ESTRs (Mirkin 2007). However, 
the mechanisms underlying the very high instability at the expanded disease-causing human 
microsatellites are not entirely replication-related. It was shown that instability at these loci is 
attributed to the ability of the repeats to form stable secondary structures, such as hairpins, 
cruciforms, etc (Mirkin 2007). The presence of secondary structures can substantially 
promote replication-slippage events, and also provide the targets for some DNA repair 
pathways, including the mismatch and base-excision pathways (Kovtun and McMurray 
 4
2008). Thus, the mis-repair of secondary structures provides the most plausible explanation 
for a dramatic age-related expansion of some disease-causing microsatellites in the non-
replicating brain (Mirkin 2007; Kovtun and McMurray 2008). Given that the repeats of some 
ESTR loci form stable secondary structures (Weitzmann et al. 1998), the contribution of 
DNA repair to the mechanisms underlying spontaneous mutation at these loci can also be 
suspected. 
Given that replication errors, including DNA polymerase slippage events, should result in a 
substantial age-related accumulation of mutations (Vijg 2007), a detailed analysis of ESTR 
mutation frequencies in aging mice may provide further insights into the mechanisms of 
spontaneous mutation at these loci. Here, using single-molecule PCR (SM-PCR), we have 
studied the effect of age on ESTR mutation accumulation in the mouse tissues with different 
cell-proliferative activity during adulthood. 
 
Materials and methods 
 
F1 C57BL/6 x CBA/Ca F1 hybrid male mice were purchased from Harlan (Bicester, 
UK) and maintained up to 96 weeks of age at the Biomedical Services Unit of University of 
Leicester. The mice were maintained on a 12-hour light/12-hours dark cycle at a standard 
temperature of 19-23oC. Standard lab chow LabDiet 5LF2 and water were supplied ad 
libitum. 
Caudal epidydimi, brain and bone marrow (BM) were collected from four groups of 
mice sacrificed at 12, 26, 48 and 96 weeks of age. DNA samples were prepared in a laminar 
flow hood as previously described (Barber et al. 2006). Approximately 5 μg of each DNA 
sample was digested with 20 U MseI for 2 h at 37oC; MseI cleaves outside the ESTR array 
and distal to the PCR primer sites used for PCR amplification and was used to render 
genomic DNA fully soluble prior to dilution. Each digested DNA sample was diluted to 
approximately 10 ng ml−1 in 5 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.5) in the presence of 5 μg ml−1 carrier 
herring sperm DNA (Sigma, Dorset, UK) prior to mutation analysis. 
 The frequency of ESTR mutation was evaluated using SM-PCR (Yauk et al. 2002; 
Barber et al. 2006). The Ms6-hm ESTR locus was amplified in 10 μl reactions using 0.4 μM 
flanking primers HM1.1F (5′-AGA GTT TCT AGT TGC TGT GA-3′) and HM1.1R (5′-GAG 
AGT CAG TTC TAA GGC AT-3′). The Expand High Fidelity PCR System (Roche, 
Mannheim, Germany) was used (0.035 U/μl) with 1 M Betaine and 200 μM each dNTP. 
Amplification was carried out at 96oC (20 sec), 58oC (30 sec), 68oC (8 min) for 30 cycles on 
a PTC-225 DNA Engine Tetrad (MJ Research, Waltham, Mass). To increase the robustness 
of the estimates of individual ESTR mutation frequencies, on average 150 amplifiable 
molecules were analyzed for each tissue for each male mouse. 
PCR products were resolved on a 40 cm long agarose gel and detected by Southern 
blot hybridization as previously described (Dubrova et al. 1998). The frequencies of ESTR 
mutation and standard errors were estimated using a modified approach proposed by 
Chakraborty (Zheng et al. 2000). DNA fragment sizes were estimated by the method of 
Southern (Southern 1979), with a 200 bp DNA Step Ladder (Promega, Madison, WI) 
included on all gels. 
 
Results 
Mutation Detection 
 
ESTR mutations in the mouse tissues were detected using SM-PCR. This technique 
involves the dilution of bulk genomic DNA followed by the amplification of multiple 
samples, each containing approximately one ESTR molecule (Yauk et al. 2002). The 
 5
frequency of ESTR mutation was analyzed at the Ms6-hm locus, which consists of a 
homogeneous array of the pentanucleotide repeat GGGCA (Kelly et al. 1989). According to 
the results of our previous studies, the frequency and spectra of somatic and germline 
mutation at this locus accumulated in young male mice (8-12 weeks old) do not substantially 
differ (Yauk et al. 2002; Barber et al. 2006; 2009; Hatch et al. 2007). 
As in a number of our previous studies (Yauk et al. 2002; Glen et al. 2008), we have 
used F1 C57BL/6 x CBA/Ca F1 hybrid male mice. These mice possess two differently-sized 
Ms6-hm alleles, derived from the C57BL/6 (~4.6 kb) and CBA/H (~3.3 kb) inbred strains, 
which substantially facilitates ESTR mutation scoring and provides the exact establishing of 
the allelic origin of mutants (fig. 1A). As in a number of previous studies on mutation 
detection at ESTR loci (Yauk et al. 2002; Dubrova 2005; Barber et al. 2006; 2009; Glen et al. 
2008), PCR products showing a shift of at least 1 mm relative to the progenitor allele were 
scored as mutant Ms6-hm molecules. Given the size of the Ms6-hm repeat unit of 5 bp (Kelly 
et al. 1989), the 1 mm shift corresponded to the gain or loss of 3 and 8 repeats for the CBA 
and C57BL alleles, respectively. This difference was attributed to the resolution of agarose 
gel electrophoresis within the range of two progenitor alleles. 
 
ESTR mutation frequencies 
 
 A summary of ESTR mutation data is presented in Table 1. Within the group of 
young 12-week-old males, the frequencies of ESTR mutation across all tissues did not 
significantly differ (fig. 1B). However, in the later cohorts mutation frequency in sperm 
showed a highly significant elevation, whereas in brain it remained unchanged. Within the 
group of old mice (48 and 96 weeks of age) significant increases were also detected in the 
BM tissue. The age-related changes in ESTR mutation frequency were equally evident 
among the mutants detected at the CBA and C57BL alleles in sperm (fig. 1C) and BM (data 
not shown). 
 A comparison of age-related changes in ESTR mutation frequencies revealed clear-
cut differences in the pattern of mutation accumulation in the mouse tissues. The most 
pronounced accumulation of ESTR mutation was observed in DNA samples extracted from 
sperm of old mice. Given that spermatogenesis in the adult mice is an ongoing process, 
characterized by a very high proliferation activity of stem cells (de Roou and Russell 2000), 
the age-related increases in ESTR mutation frequency in this tissue can therefore be 
explained by accumulation of replication-driven mutations. Indeed, the lack of any 
measurable accumulation of ESTR mutations in the brain of aging mice provides further 
support for this notion. It is well established that, although new neurons are added to the adult 
brain, the overall proliferative activity of this tissue during adulthood is extremely low (Gross 
2000). At the first glance, our results showing a moderate age-related increase in the 
frequency of ESTR mutation in the BM tissue are not entirely in line with the sperm data. 
Indeed, haemopoiesis is a dynamic process maintained by the constant proliferation of BM 
stem cells, and approximate cell cycle duration in adult mice of 3 days (Cheshier et al. 1999). 
Given this, a considerable age-related accumulation of ESTR mutations in BM, similar to that 
in sperm, is also expected. However, it should be stressed that the percentage of stem cells in 
mouse BM is very low (~9/105 cells, see Müller-Seiburg and Riblet 1996) and the samples 
extracted from this tissue are thus enriched with the genomes of non-dividing supporting 
cells. Our data on the age-related differences in the pattern of mutation accumulation are 
therefore highly consistent with the proposed involvement of DNA replication in spontaneous 
ESTR mutation. 
 An analysis of the spectra of ESTR mutation accumulated in the aging mice provided 
further evidence for the hypothesized role of DNA replication as the main mechanism 
 6
underlying spontaneous ESTR mutation. As already mentioned, the presence of secondary 
structures can substantially destabilize some human trinucleotide microsatellite loci in non-
replicating tissues, including brain (Mirkin 2007). The resulted age-related accumulation of 
microsatellite mutations at these loci is accompanied by a drastic shift in their spectrum, with 
a disproportionally high representation of gains (Mirkin 2007). According to our data (fig. 
1D), this is not the case for ESTR mutations, as their spectra in young and old animals do not 
significantly differ. Besides, the spectra of ESTR mutations accumulated in the tissues with 
different proliferation capacity during adulthood appear to be practically indistinguishable. 
Considering the results of our current and previous studies (Shanks et al. 2008), we therefore 
conclude that spontaneous ESTR mutations occur almost exclusively in replication-proficient 
cells. 
 
Rate and spectrum of ESTR mutation 
 
 Here we developed a model that describes ESTR mutation accumulation and predicts 
the distribution of mutant alleles in the tissues of aging mice. To model the ESTR mutation 
process, we assumed that it is symmetric, i.e. the probability of a mutation leading to the gain 
of k repeat units is equal to that for the loss of the same number of units. Using the approach 
previously used to describe the mutational process at conventional microsatellite loci in 
humans (Di Rienzo et al. 1994), we next approximated the distribution of ESTR mutations 
occurring during DNA replication by a symmetric geometric distribution, P{ξ=k| ξ ≠0} = 
2
1  
p (1 – p)|k|-1, k≥1, where p is the fraction of mutations involving the gain or loss of one repeat 
unit (see further details below). Here we assumed that this fraction is similar for the mutants 
derived from the CBA/Ca and C57BL/6 alleles. 
ESTR mutation accumulation was modeled in brain and sperm; the two tissues 
showing the most extreme patterns of the age-related changes in ESTR mutation frequencies. 
Given that the adult mouse brain consists of ~108 cells (Williams 2000) and assuming the 
dichotomous pattern of cell proliferation, this number can be reached by at least 27 cell 
divisions (227 ≈ 1.3 x 108). In the model we therefore set the number of cell divisions in this 
tissue to range between 27 and 33. 
The total population of stem cells in the mouse testicles consists of 70x103 cells 
(Tegelenbosch and de Rooji 1993); this number can be reached by at least 16 cell divisions 
occurring from embryonic age to puberty. Male mice become sexually mature at the age of 
~35 days, and after this point then the undifferentiated As spermatogonia undergo one mitotic 
division per ~2.8 days (de Roou and Russell 2000). Besides, during spermatogenesis each 
spermatogonium goes through 8 rounds of DNA replication before differentiating into 
spermatocytes (de Roou and Russell 2000). Using these data, the total number of cell 
divisions that have occurred from early embryonic development until the age of 12 weeks (84 
days) is 16 + (84 – 35)/2.8 + 8 = 43. For the later cohorts the number of cell divisions until 
the age of 26, 48 and 96 weeks is 62, 117 and 237, respectively. 
 
Model

model for one of the alleles. The model rests on simplified assumptions about growth of 
tissues and mutations but captures the main features of these processes. 
We split the process of cell division into two stages. The first stage corresponds to the 
period when tissues grow and it lasts until an animal becomes mature, when the second stage 
begins.

Calibration of the model  
 
 Our model has two parameters μ (mutation rate) and p (the fraction of mutations 
involving the gain or loss of a single repeat unit), which we estimated based on the 
experimental data for brain and sperm. It is assumed that for a particular allele the mutation 
rate μ is the same for both brain and sperm and that the value of p is the same for both alleles 
and both tissues. 
As discussed above, no measurable accumulation of ESTR mutation was detected in 
the brain of aging mice. Then we assume that all the mutations in the brain happen during the 
fetal and early post-natal stages of development until maturity of animals, which consists of 
27-33 divisions. Consequently, we consider brain data from animals of all ages as “frozen” 
(in terms of mutation accumulation) at the date of their maturity. This results in a larger set of 
data available for calibrating the model in the case of the brain tissue than in the case of 
sperm, making the brain calibration more statistically reliable.  
We first calibrated the model on the brain data. The calibration was done via 
matching the following characteristics of the experimental data with the model: (i) the 
variance of the mutations (for the model it is equal to N μ (2 – p) / p2 with N being the 
number of divisions; eq. (3)); (ii) the proportion of non-mutants (due to methodological limits 
in the resolving power of ESTR allelic size variants, we are restricted to measuring cells with 
no more than 2 and 7 lost/gained repeats for the CBA/Ca and C57BL/6 alleles, respectively); 
(iii) the proportion of the main class of mutants (i.e. those with more than 2 and less than 8 
lost/gained repeats) among all mutants for the CBA/Ca allele. An acceptable match was 
achieved for p = 0.4 and μ being equal to 0.01 and 0.04 for the CBA/Ca and C57BL/6 alleles, 
respectively. Then these calibrated values were verified on the sperm data using similar 
characteristics as described above. Finally, the distributions of mutants according to equation 
(4) with the calibrated values of μ and p were obtained for brain and for sperm of animals of 
various ages. Fig 2A,B represent the observed and expected distribution of ESTR mutants 
accumulated in the sperm and brain of aging mice. For both tissues the best fit was obtained 
by assuming that the fraction of mutations involving the gain or loss of one repeat unit was 
0.4, and that the mutation rates per cell division were 0.01 and 0.04 for the CBA/Ca and 
C57BL/6 alleles, respectively. 
 
Discussion 
 
The predicted rates of ESTR mutation obtained in this study are much higher than 
those for mammalian protein coding genes and microsatellite loci. For example, the in vivo 
mutation rate at the human hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosil transferase (hprt) locus is 5 
x 10-7 per cell division (Morley 1996); for replication-driven mutation at conventional 
mammalian microsatellites it ranges between 10-6 to 10-4 per cell division (Seyfert et al. 
2008). It should be noted that our estimates are close to those for the class of highly unstable 
human GC-rich minisatellites, with the rate of spontaneous mutation in the paternal germline, 
ranging from 0.5 up to 13% per gamete (Vergnaud and Denoeud F. 2000). However, as 
already mentioned, mutations at human minisatellites almost exclusively occur during 
meiosis and are attributed to complex gene-conversion like events, whereas in somatic tissues 
these loci are quite stable (Jeffreys et al. 1994; 1998). In contrast, the obtained estimates of 
 9
ESTR mutation rate in the mouse germline and brain are remarkably similar. If correct, then 
the observed differences in the frequencies of ESTR mutation accumulated in sperm and 
brain are attributed to age-related differences in the number of cell divisions that occurred in 
these tissues. Considering these data, we therefore conclude that the Ms6-hm locus can be 
regarded as the most unstable locus in the mouse genome. 
Despite the fact that in all tissues the observed frequency of ESTR mutation at the 
CBA/Ca allele significantly exceeds that for the C57BL allele, the estimates of mutation rate 
for this larger allele are at least 4-fold higher than those for the smaller CBA/Ca allele. This 
data is consistent with the results of a previous analysis of inter-strain variation in ESTR 
mutation frequencies in the mouse germline (Dubrova 2005). Our current and previous data 
therefore point toward the presence of a positive correlation between the ESTR mutation rate 
and allele size. It should be noted that such a correlation was also reported for conventional 
mammalian microsatellites (Ellegren 2004). Given that the increased number of repeats can 
further promote polymerase slippage events, the difference in the estimates of mutation rates 
for the large and smaller ESTR alleles provides more evidence for a replication-driven 
mechanism of spontaneous mutation at these loci. 
Although our study has revealed a number of striking similarities between 
conventional microsatellites and ESTR loci, the pattern of mutational processes at these loci 
differs. Using the most representative set of data on 3135 de novo paternal microsatellite 
mutations found in humans (Parentage Testing Standards Program Unit 2004), we compared 
the observed spectrum of microsatellite mutations with the geometric distribution of ESTR 
mutations used in our model (fig. 2C). While the majority of microsatellite mutations (90%) 
involved the gain or loss of one repeat unit, the best approximation of the ESTR data was 
obtained by assuming that only 40% of ESTR mutations belonged to this class. The presence 
of a considerable number of mutants involved the gain or loss of a substantial number of 
repeat units clearly differentiates the spectra of ESTR and microsatellite mutations. It should 
however be stressed that our data does not necessarily imply that these large mutational 
events arise at one site within the array, as multiple single-step mutational events could also 
occur along the large number of repeats within ESTR loci. Unfortunately, given that the Ms6-
hm locus consists of homogeneous array repeats (Kelly et al. 1989), even the direct 
sequencing of mutants cannot provide further information regarding their origin. 
 According to our experimental data, the frequency of ESTR mutation accumulated in 
sperm reaches 0.35 and 0.20 for the CBA/Ca and C57BL/6 alleles, respectively (fig. 1D). As 
a substantial number of ESTR mutants at these alleles cannot be detected by agarose 
electrophoresis, for each allele we estimated the frequency of all mutations accumulated in 
the proliferating tissues, as well as their “observed” frequency, assuming that the mutant 
bands showing at least ± 3 (CBA/Ca allele) and ± 8 repeats (C57BL/6 allele) were scored as 
mutants. For both alleles, the total frequency of accumulated mutations substantially 
exceeded the “observed” (fig. 2D). The gap between the two estimates was particularly 
pronounced for the C57BL mutants, where the total frequency of ESTR mutation reached a 
high of 0.9 within the range of observed frequencies, and a low of 0.15. We therefore 
conclude that the observed frequencies of ESTR mutation, reported here and in all previous 
studies, represent a substantial 2-4 fold underestimate of their total frequency. Given that the 
expected frequency of ESTR mutation accumulation in old animals is ~0.6 and ~0.9 for the 
CBA/Ca and C57BL/6 alleles, respectively, our data therefore suggest that up to 95% of stem 
cells in the testicles of old mice should contain at least one ESTR mutation. The pattern of 
age-related accumulation of ESTR mutations in actively proliferating tissues therefore 
resembles that for the most unstable expanded disease-causing human microsatellites (Mirkin 
2007), thus indicating that these two classes of tandem repeat loci may be equally unstable. 
 10
 In conclusion, the results of our study provide strong evidence for replication-driven 
mechanisms underlying spontaneous mutation at ESTR loci. Considering these data and the 
results of other publications, it therefore appears that spontaneous ESTR mutation is mostly 
attributed to replication slippage and these loci may therefore be regarded as a class of 
expanded microsatellites. Our estimates of ESTR spontaneous mutation rate clearly show that 
some of these loci belong to the most unstable loci in the mammalian genome. It should also 
be noted that since 1993 these loci have extensively been used for the analysis of mutation 
induction in the germline of male mice exposed to ionizing radiation, chemical mutagens and 
anticancer drugs (Dubrova et al. 1993; 1998; 2000; Fan et al. 1995; Vilarino-Guell et al. 
2003; Glen et al. 2008). The results of our study are therefore important in furthering our 
understanding of the mechanisms of mutation induction at these loci.
